LGTM

Not only is there not a "most common" approach, there are conflicting approaches in "Python-land", specifically because Python-sqlite-land has one way to do this that is diametrically opposed to the Python-PostgreSQL-land way to do this and rather different from the Python-MySQL-land way to do this.

Often times, we get to _just_ let SQLAlchemy worry about this sort of thing but, unfortunately, in this case SQLAlchemy doesn't have a standard way to do this. The best SQLAlchemy provides is using this problem as a [compiler example](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/compiler.html#utc-timestamp-function).

The discussion, essentially boils down to: 1) Should we calculate timestamps on the SQL server or should we calculate timestamps in Python on the individual workers, scheduler, and webservers; and 2) if we calculate timestamps on the SQL server, what should that code look like.

My assertion is that we should calculate the timestamps on the SQL server so that we can have a single, consistent clock for all timestamps.

What a colossal pain. I'd ask why Python can't agree on how text works but that would trivialize how really hard it is to get right (and Python is way better than it used to be at this).

We can fix that by wrapping the binary file in a unicode codec reader.

```
textstream = codecs.getreader('utf-8')(request.files['file'])
d = json.load(textstream)
```

Works in 3.5, also works in 3.6; 🤞 that it will work in 2.7.

We can also put the reader as a file level constant (no real preference on my end):

```python
UTF8_READER = codecs.getreader('utf-8')
...
d = json.load(UTF8_READER(request.files['file']))
```

If we want to support more than UTF-8, we could use [chardet](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/chardet) to determine the encoding but, in my opinion, that's overkill.

Agree with @NielsZeilemaker. The `AIRFLOW_CONN` env var prefix is used to set a connection URI via env var as shown below:
`AIRFLOW_CONN_MYSQL_DBCONN=mysql://user@localhost:3333`

To set the connection to the Airflow Metadata DB, the DB used by Airflow itself (not the connections exposed to DAGs via Admin-->connections), you would use `AIRFLOW__CORE__SQL_ALCHEMY_CONN`
